item.title: MTG Avatar: The Last Airbender – Everything You Need to Know
item.content:encoded:
Avatar: The Last Airbender makes its way to Magic: The Gathering in a little less than a month on November 21st, and we just got the rundown of the whole release at a press event. We have some new cards to show off, some new information, and we'll give you the rundown on things specific to this set, some of which you may know already. There's also a look at a Secret lair drop. 

Where Are the Avatar: The Last Airbender Commander Decks? 

To get the biggest question out of the way, we learned why there are no precon Commander decks in the set. It seems so obvious with the four types of airbending right? 

When they were preparing for this set, they sought a lot of feedback about what people wanted from an Avatar: The Last Airbender set in Magic. The team told us the surprisingly biggest thing people were most excited about was using Avatar as a way to teach people in their life to play Magic. 

That’s generally one of the bonuses to Universes Beyond, but we were told that there was so much specific feedback for Avatar they couldn’t ignore it. 

When it came down to it, they realized they only had the bandwidth to do one of two things: Commander or Jumpstart. 

With all the feedback they got early on, they went ahead with Jumpstart. 

They also added that not all of the different bending mechanics lend themselves well to a Commander deck, airbending mentioned specifically.  

What’s in the Commander’s Bundle? 

Commander is not ignored, however. They are selling a Commander’s Bundle that is very similar to gift bundles in previous sets.

It includes 9 booster packs, one collector booster, 30 Avatar: The Last Airbender lands (15 foil , 15 nonfoil), a click wheel life counter, and some Commander specific staples. 

Featuring the Avatar art above, the bundle includes five nonfoil promo cards. Three of them are the same in each bundle: a Sol Ring, Arcane Signet, and Swiftwfoot Boots. The other two are borderless versions of “classic” Commander spells. 

Jumpstart Avatar: The Last Airbender 

Jumpstart boosters make a return in Avatar: The Last Airbender, as discussed above.  If you’re not familiar, these are packs of 20 cards that are all themed around one sort of mechanic or some sort of synergy.

With Avatar, there are 46 Jumpstart themes in total. 

There will also be some cards from Avatar that are only found in Jumpstart boosters. Here’s some of them:

 

Avatar will join Arena on November 18th and will feature every card in the set, aside from some art variants that will only be in the tabletop version. 

Unique to Arena will be some sleeves, featured above. The Aang and Katara sleeves will be in various bundles you can purchase, one with a ton of packs aimed at people making decks and the other for those more interested in drafting.. 

The Sokka sleeves will be included as part of the Mastery Pass. 

There will be three pets to collect as well, featuring the animal companions from the show: Appa, a baby Appa, and Momo. 

Avatar: The Last Airbender Bonus Sheet 

There will be a lot of source material cards in the Avatar: The Last Airbender set, 61 in total. Each card will feature a frame or part of a frame of an episode from the show so all 61 episodes are represented.

If you look at the cards, in the bottom left you’ll see exactly which episode that card’s art is from as well. Check out some below.

Secret Lair – My Cabbages! 

Unsurprisingly, there will be an Avatar: The Last Airbender Secret Lair superdrop. There are still details to come on that, like the rest of the drops and the release date, but they did reveal one to us. 

I think we all saw some form of this set coming, featuring the cabbage merchant from the show. Each one features new ways his cabbages get absolutely wrecked.

Art Variants in Avatar: The Last Airbender 

Bloomburrow fans who liked the field notes treatment will be happy to see it return with Avatar. Because the world is so full of weird and unique animals, the team thought the aesthetic fit perfectly. 

Another is the borderless elemental frame, each of which will focus on a specific character and highlight the type of bending they are associated with.

item.title: Star Wars Legion Starter Sets Review - A New Hope!
item.content:encoded:
Ahead of you, the alien sun reflects of the glinting white plastoid composite plates of a battalion of Stormtroopers honing in on your position. You signal to your rebel comrades to flank them -- this could turn the tide of the war! But then you hear it... the hiss of breath that can only mean one thing: Darth Vader. These are the thrilling moments you can recreate in Star Wars Legion, the miniature wargame set in the Star Wars universe. Atomic Mass Games just released new Starter Sets for the game, coinciding with a rules refresh, and they sent us along copies to review. So follow along as we take a trip to the dark side!

What's Included In The Star Wars Legion Starter Sets?

Each of the new Star Wars Legion Starter Sets include everything one player needs to jump into the game. Atomic Mass Games sent me a copy of the Rebel Alliance Starter Set and the Galactic Empire Starter Set, so I'll take some time here to break down everything included in each.

Star Wars Legion Rebel Alliance

The Star Wars Legion Rebel Alliance Starter Set includes:

  • 36 Miniatures
    • Commander Luke Skywalker
    • Rebel Trooper Unit X2 (11 troopers per unit)
    • Rebel Commandos Unit X1 (7 troopers per unit)
    • Wookie Warrior Unit X1 (6 troopers per unit)
  • 36 27mm Bases
  • 7 Unit Cards
  • 4 Red Attack Dice
  • 4 Black Attack Dice
  • 4 White Attack Dice
  • 4 Red Defense Dice
  • 4 White Defense Dice
  • 15 Upgrade Cards
  • 10 Command Cards
  • 24 Battle Cards
  • Movement & Range Tools
  • 3 Punch Sheets

In terms of Army Building, the models included in this box make up a 600-point force of fighters. The max an army can be is 1000 - so you're well on your way to the biggest army possible just with what's included here (I'll go into more detail about the units below, and how they play).

Star Wars Legion Galactic Empire 

The Star Wars Legion Galactic Empire Starter Set includes:

  • 37 Miniatures
    • Commander Darth Vader
    • Stormtrooper Unit X2 (11 troopers per unit)
    • Scout Trooper Unit X2 (7 troopers per unit)
  • 37 27mm Bases
  • 7 Unit Cards
  • 4 Red Attack Dice
  • 4 Black Attack Dice
  • 4 White Attack Dice
  • 4 Red Defense Dice
  • 4 White Defense Dice
  • 15 Upgrade Cards
  • 10 Command Cards
  • 24 Battle Cards
  • Movement & Range Tools

The same is true with this Starter set, giving you access to 600 points of units to give you a big leg up in your journey toward the dark side!

How Do You Play Star Wars Legion?

Star Wars Legion is a miniature wargame set within the Star Wars universe (obviously), and players will each field an army all belonging to a faction - we're reviewing the Galactic Empire and Rebel Alliance starter sets here, but there are also soon-released Separatist Alliance army and Galactic Republic army Starter Sets coming.

In the game, you'll field your army under the keen eye of a commander - in these boxes the Empire starts with Vader and the Rebel Alliance starts with Luke... pretty classic.

You'll take turns activating your units, who have all their stats and abilities represented on cards (included with the starter set, and available for download). As you move your units into position, you'll take shots and begin firing off large pools of dice to see if you've hit your opponent.

Maneuvering around terrain, zipping across the field with speeders, blasting your enemy away with blaster fire... it's all here, and when you're in the thick of battle it feels just like the best fights and skirmishes from the series. Whether the goal of the game is to claim objectives, hold important battlefield points on the map, or just disintegrate your enemies, no other tabletop game I've played captures the Star Wars vibe.

Star Wars Legion Rebel Alliance Unit Breakdown

The Rebel Alliance Starter Set comes with four unique units: Luke Skywalker, Rebel Trooper Unit (2x), Rebel Commandos Unit, and Wookie Warriors Unit. Let's take a quick look at each one.

First up is Luke Skywalker, your commander and the hero of our story (sorry Solo stans, I'll always be a "main protagonist" kinda guy). Luke is a very slippery commander, with the ability to use the force to leap across the battlefield, while inspiring those around him to keep going even when they're being suppressed by enemy fire. His blaster has a nice range, but it's his lightsaber that can really knock your opponents around.

From there, we have your everyday Rebel Troopers, who are run of the mill in most ways, but what makes them special is how their ability to gain, spend, and re-gain dodge tokens to get out of trouble. The Rebel Commandos bring more expertise to the tabletop, creeping around the battlefield, scouting ahead and jumping into the action in a surprise burst, and decreasing the cover of their enemies.

Finally, we have a fun surprise inclusion in this set, the Wookie Warriors! Previous sets and releases have shied away from including Wookies in starter sets, as we don't see any Wookies joining the fight (beyond my main man, Chewbacca) in the original trilogy. But I think their inclusion is very smart, as it not only brings some diversity to the army list, but also visually breaks up the camo and beige in a nice way.

The Wookies are, as you might expect, a real powerhouse unit in this army. They're the berserkers of this army, able to charge in, bash heads, and spend tokens to increase their odds.

All in all, it's an Army Set designed to strike fast, get in and get out, and deal as much surgically precise damage as possible. But what happens when a sneaky, shifting army comes up against the full might of the galactic empire?

Star Wars Legion Galactic Empire Unit Breakdown

The Galactic Empire Starter Set comes with three unique units: Darth Vader, Stormtrooper Unit (2x), and Scout Trooper Unit (2x). How do they play, and does this Starter Set feel different from the Rebel set?

Let's start with the Dark Father himself, Darth Vader! Vader is just as you'd expect him to be, a walking tank of death. With high health, the ability to force other friendly units around him to move, and the ability to make free attacks after moving - he's a serious problem once he gets into the fray.

His lightsaber can easily tear apart enemy tanks and infantry alike, and it's a risky move to shoot at him because he might just deflect your blasts back at you. I love the way these rules capture how terrifying it would be to actually face him on the battlefield.

From there, the list gets a little less complicated, but no less deadly! The basic Stormtroopers have the Precise keyword (hilarious), which allows them to spend aim tokens to re-roll their shots.

And the Scout Troopers actually have the exact same keywords as the Rebel Commandos, except that they can Scout ahead at a longer range - meaning they can get further into the battlefield when they're set up on the table.

Star Wars Legion Starter Sets Final Thoughts

Do the Star Wars Legion Galactic Empire and Rebel Alliance Starter Sets feel distinct from one another? Absolutely yes, as the Rebel Alliance is all about being harder to hit, while their commander Luke Skywalker hops around the battlefield. The Galactic Empire, on the other hand, feels more like the slow crawl of inevitable doom coming toward you. Vader doesn't move fast, but you're in extreme trouble when he makes contact.

You want to play your Rebels as a strike force, getting in and out while Luke and the Commandos move around the battlefield securing objectives. As a Galactic player, your goal is to give Vader covering fire as he plods toward objectives, slashing and dashing his way around the map.

This creates an incredible, dynamic tension between the two Starter Sets (which, as a reminder, aren't sold together - but I think it's worth showing them as contrasts to one another). With streamlined rules (mostly just quality of life upgrades and a major change to how units are deployed), these boxes are a smart, thoughtful introduction to the game. A must for wargaming and Star Wars fans alike!

The copies of the Starter Sets used in this review were provided by Asmodee USA.
